citation-title.titletext: Modeling and Use of Context in Action

affiliation.ce:source-text: Patrick Brezillon LIP6 Sorbonne University Paris France
Roy M. Turner School of Computing and Information Science University of Maine Orono USA.

abstract.publishercopyright: © ISTE Ltd 2022 The rights of Patrick Brézillon and Roy M. Turner
abstract.ce:para: This book brings together current research and adopts a pragmatic approach to modeling and using context to solve real-world problems. The editors were instrumental in creating - and continue to be involved in - the interdisciplinary research community, centered around the biennial CONTEXT (International and Interdisciplinary Conference on Modeling and Using Context) conference series, focused on studying context and its implications for artificial intelligence, software applications, psychology, philosophy, linguistics, neuroscience, as well as other fields.The first three chapters lay the foundations, looking at the lessons learned over the past 25 years and arguing for a continued shift toward more pragmatic approaches. The remaining chapters contain contributions to pragmatic context-based research from a wide range of domains, including technological problems - such as subway incident management and autonomous underwater vehicle control - identifying emotions from speech without understanding the words, anonymization in a world where privacy is increasingly threatened, teaching in context and improving management teaching in a business school.

citation-title.titletext: Pragmatic Research on Context Modeling and Use

affiliation.ce:source-text: Patrick Brézillon LIP6 Sorbonne University Paris France
Roy M. Turner School of Computing and Information Science University of Maine Orono USA.

abstract.publishercopyright: © ISTE Ltd 2022 The rights of Patrick Brézillon and Roy M. Turner
abstract.ce:para: Pragmatic approaches to solving problems in artificial intelligence arise due to rapid technological evolution as well as the complexity of real-world tasks. This chapter discusses pragmatic approaches from the perspective of agents (human and AI) using data, information and knowledge in context. Context plays a pivotal role in the development of information and knowledge. Artificial Intelligence research has, over time, also become increasingly aware of the role context and contextual knowledge plays in problem-solving. Mental model assembles, organizes and structures all the contextual elements encountered by the actor during their past experience with this task realization, decision-making or problem-solving. The chapter compares three examples of pragmatic research in context sensitive reasoning: context-based reasoning, contextual graphs and context-mediated behavior. Pragmatic research mainly concerns context-based systems, and it looks to represent how to behave in specific contexts.

citation-title.titletext: Modeling and Using Context: 25 Years of Lessons Learned

affiliation.ce:source-text: Patrick Brézillon LIP6 Sorbonne University Paris France
Patrick Brézillon LIP6 Sorbonne University Paris France

abstract.publishercopyright: © ISTE Ltd 2022 The rights of Patrick Brézillon and Roy M. Turner
abstract.ce:para: This chapter presents the results of 25 years of research on modeling and using context in real-world applications. One of the milestone was an operational definition of context relating it to a focus (problem-solving, decision-making, task realization). The operational definition of context and the in depth study of different aspects of context have allowed the design and implementation of a context-based representation formalism called contextual graphs (CxG). Contextual knowledge constitutes a set of elements more or less related to a focus in a flat way. The key point of context modeling is the association of conceptual and operational views, ensuring direct implementation of the conceptual model of context. The shared context concerns a task realized by a group of actors. The phase of shared-context building does not only concern contextual knowledge but also external knowledge that the proposal originator has. The chapter outlines the value of the extension of the CxG formalism.

Patrick Brézillon LIP6 Sorbonne University Paris France

abstract.publishercopyright: © ISTE Ltd 2022 The rights of Patrick Brézillon and Roy M. Turner
abstract.ce:para: Context-based intelligent systems are those that not only focus on problems but also on the context in which the problems are to be solved. This chapter discusses the requirements needed for pragmatic context-based systems in general, as well as for two broad classes, in particular: context-based intelligent assistant systems and context-based intelligent autonomous agents. It also discusses pragmatic context-based intelligent systems. Early Artificial Intelligence systems were general-purpose systems, such as the General Problem Solver, theorem provers, early planning systems and game-playing programs centered around the minimax algorithm. Context is so important in any form of reasoning that it should be taken into account as a primary determinant of how to behave. Pragmatic approaches persevered, pointing out that from a pragmatic perspective, context is what constrains a reasoner's problem-solving without directly intervening.

citation-title.titletext: Activating the Context for Learning and Teaching: Findings from the TEEC Project

affiliation.ce:source-text: Claire ANJOU Université TELUQ Quebec Canada
Thomas FORISSIER CRREF (EA 4538) Université des Antilles Guadeloupe France
Jacqueline BOURDEAU Université TELUQ Montreal Canada
Valéry PSYCHÉ Université TELUQ Quebec Canada
Lamprini CHARTOFYLAKA CRREF (EA 4538) Université des Antilles Guadeloupe France
Alain STOCKLESS UQAM Montreal Canada

abstract.publishercopyright: © ISTE Ltd 2022 The rights of Patrick Brézillon and Roy M. Turner
abstract.ce:para: The last decade has seen a turning point in research on context effect-based education with the implementation of the TEEC project (Educational Technologies for Teaching in Context). This project is aimed at conceptualizing a techno pedagogical model where context, in the various forms that it may take, occupies a central role. This chapter's primary objective is to summarize and compile the work progress, and results achieved within the TEEC project. Fundamentally, the TEEC project relies on the implementation of multiple experiments using the context effect-based pedagogical approach. The chapter discusses notion of context in education, context effects in education and digital technologies in education. It also discusses the global research focuses on the TEEC project. The TEEC project focuses on bringing together two different research approaches in a domain where the intellectual traditions are quite different: the French and the Quebecois.

citation-title.titletext: Pragmatic Reasoning in Context: Context-Mediated Behavior

affiliation.ce:source-text: Roy M. Turner School of Computing and Information Science University of Maine Orono USA.
Roy M. Turner School of Computing and Information Science University of Maine Orono USA.

abstract.publishercopyright: © ISTE Ltd 2022 The rights of Patrick Brézillon and Roy M. Turner
abstract.ce:para: This chapter discusses a pragmatic approach to context-based intelligent reasoning, context-mediated behavior (CMB). CMB explicitly represents contextual information as contextual schemas (c-schemas), which represent classes of situations that have implications for how an agent should behave. Artificial intelligence systems have always incorporated some contextual knowledge. The chapter reports on work in the author's lab on one long running approach to pragmatic contextual reasoning called context-mediated behaviour. Descriptive contextual knowledge is just that: it describes the context. Problem-solving contexts are unique because they are used to prevent a premature exit from the context, or at least exiting without taking appropriate actions to cleanly leave the context. CMB has been applied in the domains of: medical diagnosis, intelligent mission control of physical systems, multiagent systems and, most recently, context dependent deep learning.

citation-title.titletext: Using Context to Help Identify the Emotional State of a Human in a Conversation

affiliation.ce:source-text: Andreas H. MARPAUNG University of Central Florida Orlando USA
Avelino J. GONZALEZ University of Central Florida Orlando USA

abstract.publishercopyright: © ISTE Ltd 2022 The rights of Patrick Brézillon and Roy M. Turner
abstract.ce:para: This chapter describes how the use of context can help identify the emotion being expressed by a person when they are uttering sounds paralinguistically – that is, vocalizing sounds without understandable words. It also describes the context modeling process used and the overall system designed to do the affect recognition. The research focuses on identifying the emotions felt by a human speaker whose situation is known and described in text. Geneva Multi-modal Emotion Portrayals contains the two input components: audio files containing recordings of meaningless, the aforementioned accompanying brief textual description of the imaginary situation faced by the actors who uttered the sounds recorded in each of the audio files. The chapter uses context to improve the accuracy of the state-of- the-art paralinguistic affect recognition systems, which are all based on applying classifiers of different types to the sounds emitted by the speaker.

citation-title.titletext: Context-Driven Behavior: A Proactive Approach to Contextual Reasoning

affiliation.ce:source-text: Christian WILSON School of Computing and Information Science University of Maine Orono USA
Christian WILSON School of Computing and Information Science University of Maine Orono USA

abstract.publishercopyright: © ISTE Ltd 2022 The rights of Patrick Brézillon and Roy M. Turner
abstract.ce:para: This chapter discusses a framework for a novel form of contextual reasoning. Unlike existing contextual reasoning frameworks, which allow an agent to apply its contextual knowledge after it is operating in an instance of a known context, the model discussed allows an agent to reason about context proactively. The chapter describes a framework for a proactive model of contextual reasoning. The chapter discusses challenges associated with a proactive model of contextual reasoning. It also discusses context and contextual knowledge as it pertains to context-driven behavior. A context-driven agent does not need to predict all future contexts but rather only those contexts that will have immediate implications for its behavior. Prescriptive knowledge tells an agent how to behave while the context is active. Once context prediction is complete, the agent will attempt to identify any context-inappropriate behavior related to the problem-solving scenario.

citation-title.titletext: Context-Based Personal Data Discovery for Anonymization

affiliation.ce:source-text: Hassane TAHIR Links Consultants Paris France
Patrick BRÉZILLON LIP6 Sorbonne University Paris France

abstract.publishercopyright: © ISTE Ltd 2022 The rights of Patrick Brézillon and Roy M. Turner
abstract.ce:para: The rapid technological change and globalization have created new challenges for the protection of personal data, with the scale of their collection and sharing increasing exponentially. The anonymization of data is one of the methods of complying with the General Data Protection Regulation. This chapter presents how to consider context in the procedures of personal data discovery to improve the anonymization process adopted by a company to protect its corporate applications and those of its international subsidiaries. Anonymization is a technique that irreversibly prevents the identification of an individual's personal data. Contextual graphs software can be used as a decision-making tool to assist business analysts in personal data classification when working on databases with too many tables. Business analysts' practices can be simply represented by the different actions in the paths of a contextual graph.

Régis MAUBREY IPAG Business School Paris France

abstract.publishercopyright: © ISTE Ltd 2022 The rights of Patrick Brézillon and Roy M. Turner
abstract.ce:para: This chapter presents a dynamic model of situated management learning, a tool for teaching, practicing and researching management. The model is inspired by a phenomenologically and psychologically plausible philosophy of action, equally rooted in desire and belief. The chapter reports a method of modeling and using context in management decision-making and problem-solving that we call a situated learning approach. A management insight is then defined as the sudden or reflective understanding of what is going on, and what needs to be done, in a particular evolving situation confronting a corporate manager faced with a decision to make or a problem to solve. Feedback is organized in three waves: first, the members of the learning team are asked to give themselves feedback, then the class is asked for feedback, and finally the teacher completes the feedback process. Reflective distance supports theoretical, political, moral and ethical learning.
